repnme.cdata!:
India - Maharashtra Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            marginally satisfactory. The key lessons learned are: 1)
            Attention should be given up front to the institutional and
            financial arrangements for operation & maintenance
            (O&M) of the new facilities. 2) The entity responsible
            for overall project coordination involving various agencies
            should be fully staffed prior to implementation and be
            empowered to approve key project milestones and impose
            penalties for non-adherence to these milestones. 3) The
            community participation arrangements should be clearly
            defined prior to appraisal. 4) Planning of water supply and
            sanitation facilities should have a long-term horizon and
            investments should be planned to allow for infrastructure to
            be built in a phased manner. 5) The respective roles of
            government agencies, communities, nongovernmental
            organizations (NGOs), and local governments in the planning,
            implementation, and O&M of water and sanitation
            facilities should be clearly defined during project
            preparation. 6) Criteria for the selection of NGOs should be
            clear, well targeted and transparent, and agreed by project
            appraisal. 7) Adequate orientation and capacity building for
            the staff of the public sector agencies and NGOs involved
            should be made available as early as possible during
            implementation. 8) To ensure affordability of the piped
            regional water schemes, lower-cost alternatives should be
            pursued and users' willingness to pay should be
            assessed at an early stage.

repnme.cdata!:
Socio-economic study of the beneficiaries
            of the proposed water supply and sanitation programme : report

abstracts.cdata!:
Rural water supply and sanitation are
            important factors that could improve the quality of life of
            the people living in villages. Since water and sanitation
            are prominent factors in the transmission of the more
            serious diseases of the developing world, a programme of
            safe drinking water, construction of latrines and rural
            sanitation has been taken up by the Government of
            Maharashtra with World Bank assistance. The project aims to
            facilitate improvement in the water supply and sanitation
            facilities of the beneficiaries and thereby reduction in the
            incidence of diseases due to impure water supply and poor
            sanitation. This is a report of a socio-economic study of
            the beneficiaries conducted in order to collect benchmark
            information, which could be used in comparing with the
            results obtained in subsequent years; to collect benchmark
            information concerning the willingness and capacity to pay
            for the improved water supply and sanitation facilities; and
            to provide guidelines for the implementation of the programme.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Maharashtra Rural Water Supply and
            Environmental Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will raise the standard of
            living in rural areas through improved health productivity,
            by expanding access to potable rural water supply systems
            and environmental sanitation facilities.  The rural water
            supply component will include about 75 large regional piped
            water supply schemes, 170 individual village piped water
            schemes and the installation of about 3,000 hand pumps.  In
            a country where the incidence of water-related diseases is
            high and public sanitation standards poor, the project will
            promote enhanced approaches to environmental sanitation and
            health communications through the development of new
            strategies and the implementation of those strategies
            through innovative programs.  The environmental sanitation
            component will promote the disposal of waste water in
            villages with piped water supply through improved drainage
            and the construction of low cost latrines.  The health
            communications component will create greater community
            awareness and demand for improved hygiene and environmental
            sanitation and will give field staff in the Department of
            Public Health a greater role in promoting a cleaner
            environment.  NGOs will play a key role in the planning and
            implementation of the environmental sanitation and health
            communications components.  The project will also strengthen
            the water quality monitoring system in rural areas
            throughout the state.

India - Maharashtra Rural Water Supply and
